paragraphs.name: 573b
paragraphs.text: Kudelski Security, a long-time client of Crema, reached out to us in a bit of a bind: they needed MVP designs for a new platform â€” fast. Iâ€™m a Product Manager at Crema, so Iâ€™m usually in some of the early sales conversations with clients. previewContent.subtitle: How to use Rails virtual attributes? What is their main purpose? Keep some data without creating the new column in the database.

paragraphs.text: Rails virtual attributes use cases

paragraphs.name: a2cb
paragraphs.text: You want to keep some data but do not want to create the new column in the database? Your data should be stored in a form different from the one the user got to deal with?

paragraphs.name: ba5c
paragraphs.text: The virtual attributes could help you! Letâ€™s look at the main cases that come to our aid.

paragraphs.name: eac6
paragraphs.text: Photo by Bram Van Oost on Unsplash

paragraphs.name: 341b
paragraphs.text: What is â€˜Virtual Attributeâ€™?

paragraphs.name: 839f
paragraphs.text: The Virtual Attribute is a class attribute, which has no representation in the database. It becomes available after object initialization and remains alive while the object itself is available (like the instance methods). We defined some cases, where virtual attributes are useful and make the code and development more understandable.

previewContent2.subtitle: How to use Rails virtual attributes? What is their main purpose? Keep some data without creating the new column in the database.

paragraphs.name: d1a2
paragraphs.text: Everyone is not Ops

paragraphs.name: 2d7d
paragraphs.text: Yesterday was Sysadmin Appreciation Day. There was a lot of chatter about what the future of Operations will look like, a recurrent theme being that in this day and age, Operations is â€œeveryoneâ€™s jobâ€ or that â€œeveryone is Opsâ€.

paragraphs.name: 1bb7
paragraphs.text: While I think people who believe this have their hearts in the right place, itâ€™s a tad simplistic or opportunistic view. The reality on the ground happens to be more nuanced, and the problems facing most organizations are highly unlikely to be solved by idealistic chants of â€œeveryone is Opsâ€.

paragraphs.text: Testing Microservices, the sane way

paragraphs.name: f495
paragraphs.text: Thereâ€™s no dearth of information or best-practices or books about how best to test software. This post, however, focuses solely on testing backend services and not desktop software or safety critical systems or GUI tools or frontend applications and what have you.

paragraphs.name: b30e
paragraphs.text: Distributed systems means different things to different people.

paragraphs.name: dfc8
paragraphs.text: For the purpose of this post, by â€œdistributed systemâ€ I mean a system composed of many moving parts, each with different guarantees and failure modes which, together, work in unison to provide a business feature. This certainly isnâ€™t close to the canonical definition of a â€œdistributed systemâ€, but these are the kind of systems I have most experience working with and Iâ€™d argue these are the kind of systems the vast majority of us build and operate. Albeit weâ€™re talking about a distributed system, the terminology du jour is â€œmicroservices architectureâ€.

previewContent2.subtitle: Thereâ€™s no dearth of information or best-practices or books about how best to test software. This post, however, focuses solely on testingâ€¦

paragraphs.text: Go: Monitor Pattern
Illustration created for â€œA Journey With Goâ€, made from the original Go Gopher, created by Renee French.

Go implements the monitor pattern thanks to the sync package and the sync.Cond structure. The monitor pattern allows our goroutines to wait for a specific condition while entering in a sleeping mode without blocking our execution or consuming resources.

paragraphs.name: 1c82
paragraphs.text: Condition variable in action

paragraphs.name: cc6c
paragraphs.text: Letâ€™s start with an example of this pattern in order to see the advantages it could bring. I will use the example provided in the presentation by Bryan Mills :
